newsitem.title: UK: Cross border investment increases in 1996 -study.
newsitem.headline: Cross border investment increases in 1996 -study.

text.p: Cross border investment increased in 1996 over 1995, with double-digit growth rates in both Europe and the United States, a report on global equity investment flows from fund data company Technimetrics shows.

Total U.S. holdings abroad climbed to 17.6 percent during Q1 1996, after a 0.9 percent rise in Q4 1995, while international equity investment held by European institutions rose 12.5 percent in Q1, up from an increase of just 5.8 percent the previous quarter.

Europe was by far the biggest destination for U.S. institutional investment in non-U.S. equities, attracting some $217 billion (52.7 percent) at end-March 1996 against $181 billion at end-December 1995.
Asia Pacific was the next most attractive area (24.8 percent of international holdings), followed by Canada and Latin America and all showed increased investment over the last quarter.

Technimetrics said U.S. investors are also beginning to "show measurable interest" in the developing markets of eastern Europe, starting with Russia's Lukoil ADR in January and increased holdings in Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic.
Latin American holdings are also increasing, especially in Brazil and Mexico, where U.S. holdings are now higher than they were in December 1994 just before Mexico's financial crisis.
Latin American equities represent 7.3 percent of U.S. international investment, up from 6.4 percent a year ago.

European investors continued their preference for non-domestic European investments, which grew by nine percent during the quarter. They now make up 43.6 percent of European cross-border investment, from 38.4 percent a year ago.
"The increase came at the expanse of equities in Asia-Pacific and the U.S. and Canada," Technimetrics said.
European investors also like the look of eastern European markets but have backed away from Latin American stocks during the quarter, with holdings flat compared with Q4 1995.
European Latin American equity holdings are still higher (2.3 percent) than they were a year ago (two percent).
